title: England cricket team
summary: The England cricket team represents England and Wales in international cricket. England and Australia were the first teams to play a Test match in 1877

Widely referred to as the Home of Cricket,  it is the home of Middlesex County Cricket Club, the England and Wales Cricket Board (ECB), and the European Cricket Council (ECC).

The first overseas tour occurred in September 1859 with England touring North America. This team had six players from the All-England Eleven, six from the United All-England Eleven and was captained by George Parr.

The first Test match on English soil occurred in 1880 with England victorious; this was the first time England fielded a fully representative side with W.G. Grace included in the team

The 1970s, for the England team, can be largely split into three parts. The early 70s saw Ray Illingworth's side dominate world cricket. The mid-1970s were more turbulent. England were badly exposed as ageing and lacking in good fast bowling against the 1974–75 Australians, losing that series 4–1 to lose the Ashes. The side of 1977–80 contained some young players who went on to become England greats,

Michael Vaughan took over, with players encouraged to express themselves. England won five consecutive Test series prior to facing Australia in the 2005 Ashes series, taking the team to second place in the ICC Test Championship table.

The 2009 Ashes series featured the first Test match played in Wales, at Sophia Gardens, Cardiff. England drew the match thanks to a last wicket stand by bowlers James Anderson and Monty Panesar. A victory for each team followed before the series was decided at The Oval. Thanks to fine bowling by Stuart Broad and Graeme Swann and a debut century by Jonathan Trott, England regained the Ashes.

England won their first ever ICC world championship, the 2010 World Twenty20, with a seven-wicket win over Australia in Barbados..

After finishing as runners-up in the ICC Champions Trophy, England faced Australia in back-to-back Ashes series. A 3–0 home win secured England the urn for the fourth time in five series. However, in the return series, they found themselves utterly demolished in a 5–0 defeat, their second Ashes whitewash in under a decade
He is is currently vice-captain of the England cricket team.
He holds the record for England's fastest ever Test double-century

England was defeated by their arch-rivals Australia by seven runs in the most closely fought World Cup final to date in Kolkata's Eden Gardens stadium.
A strong performance by England in the 1992 Cricket World Cup in which the England team finished as runners-up for the second consecutive World Cup
It was won by England, who defeated Australia in the final. Kevin Pietersen was named as player of the tournament.

The ICC T20 World Cup (earlier known as ICC World Twenty20) is the international championship of Twenty20 International cricket. The tournament currently consists of 16 teams, comprising the top eight teams from the rankings at the given deadline and four other teams chosen through the T20 World Cup Qualifier.
